Yes Diary. Bryan is a pesk. He is the biggest pesk at school and I despise him...

And yet I have a crush on him...

"Wait, did I read that right?"

And yet I have a crush on him...

The next several seconds felt like hours, as you process the sentence you just read. Was this some kind of joke? Did Emily only put that there expecting you to come across her diary one of these days? Yeah, that had to be it. There was still more to read, so you kept reading

Yes Diary, I admit it. I like him. Like "like LIKE" him. Confusing, I know. I could hardly believe it myself. But lately whenever I look at him my heart races - he always looks so cool, even when he's being a pesky trouble maker. He's also one of the fastest boys at PE and as much as J hated him taking the dodgeballs he looked so manly when he took out the opposing team.

Your cheeks were read. What kind of joke was this?

Yes Diary, as much as pesk as he is, I have a crush on him. This feeling in my heart is so strong I could just run up to him and hug him. Hug him real tight and - him

You freeze. "That was not what I thought I read, was it?" You comment anxiously before rereading the last sentence. You read up to that word again. That second to last word. The word you hoped you would come across as you read slowly

K-I-S-S

...

"OH MY GOD!" You scream, throwing the book to thr ground. Breathing heavily, you stare at where you had thrown the diary, trying to process everything you had just now read.

No, it was not some cruel joke after all. This was really. This was very real.

Emily Williams likes you. Like "like LIKES" you.

You wanted to throw up really bad.

You bury your head into the pillow, hoping this was all some bad dream. You pinched youself even. But nope you were still here, in Emily's room, in Emily's body. And Emily was the girl who secretly had a crush on you. And she was probably going to try to give you cooties too!

The rest of the weekend was slow and uneventful, aside from still being stuck in Emily's body. Eventually you had to change out of the swimming suit and into pajamas - on the insistence of Emily's mother - you tried to keep your eyes shut as you put on the pajamas. You also spent the rest of the weekend trying to forget the contents of the diary you had read, but no matter how hard you tried you could not forget the shocking revelation that Emily wanted to - you gaghed in your mouth jusy thinking of the "K word".

Soon the weekend was over and you had to go back to school. Emily's mother made you take a shower - an experience you didn't want to think about either - and since both of Emily's shorts were conviently dirty you were stuck having to wear a skirt. "This feels so weird" was all you could think while trying to walk in the skirt.

At the bus stop, you start thinking about what you and Emily would talk about in regards to the body swap - and then you remembered the contents of the diary. You feel nauseous again. You weren't sure whether to confront Emily on this crush of her's - she might get mad at you and just leave you like this. However you were afraid that she might try to sneak onto you and infect you with cooties...
14311322111.title: Emily's Diary

choices: Stuffed yourself in the most boy clothes you could find
Cleaned yourself up and found boy clothes
Cleaned self up and dressed like Emily
1431132212.content:
The weekend alone at Emily's house is the most surreal experience you've ever had. Alone with strangers, you resolved to hole up in Emily's room. Stay out of sight and away from any questions her parents might have. Luckily, you only have to emerge once or twice for meals. The parents seem pretty willing to just leave Emily be.

The trouble begins with your first day back at school. You had only changed once the entire weekend: from swimsuit to pajamas. You kept your eyes closed the entire time too. Now here you were, about to go... outside. Where people tended to be. The amount of dread you felt at this moment was tremendous.

But there was no avoiding it. What did you do to prepare for "Emily's" day at school?
1431132212.title: Meet her at school

choices: You manage to get Emily alone to talk
The two kids get split up again
14311322121.content:
You couldn't be bothered to do more than this. As soon as you and Emily figured this out, you'd be back to your old body in no time.

And so, in jeans and the most plain t-shirt you could track down through Emily's closet of girly nonsense, you trudged onto the bus grumpily. Well, at least you were with people you knew now. Your friends Brian and Derek were on the bus.

"Hey guys!" You wave automatically, forgetting your appearance for the moment.

They fix you with a glare and scrunched up their noses.

"What's that smell?"

"Smells like the tattletale ate dog vomit." The two guffawed, the other children joining in.

You didn't know how to react. Those two were your friends! They've never been this mean to you before...

...Mean to you. Crap.

You stomp over to the back of the bus, hoping to melt into the plastic seats. This was the worst. You couldn't even talk to your old friends anymore. No one else seemed to want Emily to sit down next to them. You were... alone.

The bus reached the school building and all the students flushed out of the bus and into the school. You scanned the crowd for the most familiar face of the bunch and, sure enough, found yours looking back at you across the way. "He" was panicky, scared by the possibility of anyone looking at "him" for too long.

You had to admit, you were feeling pretty similar all things considered.
14311322121.title: Stuffed yourself in the most boy clothes you co...

143113221211.content:
The two of you quickly duck around the corner, away from prying eyes.

"What are you wearing?" Emily sounded horrified in your voice.

"It's jeans and a shirt."

"Oh my go- did you even shower? You smell awful. I smell awful."

You put your hands on your hips. Or Emily's hips. The hips you currently possess. "So you wanted me to shower in your body?"

Her mouth scrunched up in disgust. "Okay, fine, I get it, perv."

Of course that word she knew.

The two of you stared at each other for a long moment. You poked her (your?) cheek.

"Ow! What was that for?"

"Nothing. It's just.... weird."

"...yeah."

A quiet silence.

"...what now?"

She rubbed her chin. Your chin. His chin? God, this was frigging confusing.

"I think we have to research. Find ways to reverse this and keep trying."

"And until then we just... keep each other lives?"

"You don't sound like you have any better ideas."

Your rolled your eyes. Her eyes. Crap. "Alright, then ground rules. You don't make me look like a little wimp."

"And you don't make me look like a slimy weasel."

"Oh so you want me looking out of character?"

She glared daggers. "The only reason I'm not knocking your block off is because it's my block I'd be knocking."

You consider this. "....I'm not sure that simile works."

"It's perfectly understandable for civilized people. And it's a metaphor."

"You know I don't know those words."

She huffs in irritation. "Have you ever paid attention in class?"

"Have you ever not been a brat? No, stop, this is stupid. We're setting rules. Is there anything else we should know about each other?"

And the two of you continued to exchange information. You had several siblings, one of them in college, so you quizzed Emily to make sure she got it right.

As for her, she informed you that her mom kept talking about having another kid eventually, but nothing had come of it and her dad was always busy. Sometimes, you would have to make your own meals.

You explained to her your friends and who was who and how she should behave around them.

She described a list of things the teachers liked and how Ms. Smith liked to eat PB and Js with her during lunch. God, what a nerd, you groaned.

But soon, the rules were established and you both shook hands on it (she refused to let you spit in your hand).

"We won't have to do this for long."

"We'll be back in our old bodies before you know it."
143113221211.title: You manage to get Emily alone to talk

choices: You get into a fight with a boy on the first day
You find yourself facing girl drama
1431132212112.content:
Three years passed. Nothing had switched you back.

Emily had pretty much sabotaged your reputation immediately. It wasn't her fault, you had to reluctantly admit. She just wasn't as rough and tumble as you. And your friends? Were very rough and tumble. By the end of the year, Brian and Derek decided you got "lame" and avoided you. By the end of the second year, they had shifted to picking on Emily-in-you. She slowly shifted back to being a teacher's pet, although not as much of a tattletale. She read books alone at lunch until you started sitting with her. Still, she seemed as happy as someone could be for someone who looked like her life was tumbling down the drain.

"Your family is so... energetic." She complained one day. "There's so many of them and the younger ones keep wanting me to play with them. How am I supposed to keep up?"

Once you managed to get invited to your own house one day, just to see how things were doing. The parents seemed happy and content and all your brothers and sisters were eager and hyper as ever. But they didn't recognize you and Emily got made fun of for bringing a girl to play.

If you bugged her about this life ruination, she would be quick to remind you of your own failings. You just couldn't hack the classes and her grades fell. Teachers grew concerned, then annoyed, then ignored you again. It kind of hurt. You were starting to like Ms. Smith and the other teachers being so pleasant to you.

You considered trying for sports, but the girl's teams were lacking at this school. Besides, Emily made it very clear she didn't want you anywhere with her body on the field. She almost joined ballet before you shut that down in turn. So neither of you tried for clubs. Pretty soon, Emily and you only had each other at and after school. You don't know if you'd call it a friendship. You had fun, once in a while, hanging out.

Emily's mom got pregnant after all. Twins, a boy and a girl, Ethan and Sophie. At first it seemed to be going well and both of the parents seemed to actually be present for a while. But eventually the moment passed. The dad went back to work and the mom did whatever she pleased. You had to help around the house a lot when they weren't paying attention. Emily was so excited to meet them. She was heartbroken when they scurried away from her.

Unconsciously, you had trouble thinking of that body as you anymore. Sure, that was you, and you desperately wanted to get back to your old life. But you looked at your body and thought "there's Emily." People called you Emily and you looked up. You looked in the mirror and thought "there I am." It was hard not to pick up the habit. Still. Very disconcerting if you thought about it too long.

The two of you met at the local playground. This was a conversation that had to go down in person.

"...Things are gonna be different this year."

You blinked in surprise. You didn't think Emily would be the one to venture forth on this topic. But you waited patiently.

"I mean..." She dragged a hand through her hair. "We can't change too much, obviously. We have to keep things within reason for when we switch back."

"Obviously."

"But... we couldn't even last a year acting like each other. I don't think we lasted a month."

You leaned against a swingset, blowing hair out of your face. "Tell me about it. Even trying to study like you gives me a headache."

"So..." She took a deep breath. "I want to try new things in middle school. Things outside of our ground rules."

"You and me both."

"Alright. Good."

The two of you stared at each other for another long moment. Awkward silences were becoming a trademark of your relationship. It was hard for things not to be awkward when you were staring at what should be your own life.

"Obviously, no ballet or the like. It's bad enough for your reputation, but I'm the one who would get bullied for it."

"Right. And I won't.... I don't know, shave my head or anything crazy. I don't want it crazy long, but... I'll keep it chin-length."

She nods. "...I was kind of thinking about trying an instrument."

"What, you don't want to be a princess anymore?"

She snorts in surprise. "Come on, I was eight! We're teenagers now."

"So I can finally change your room."

There was a flash of anger on her face before she sighed."...Yeah. Yeah, I don't want that embarrassing old stuff up there anymore. If you put in a game system or something, just try not to make me look dorky."

You didn't have the heart to tell her you de-pinkified the room last year. Emily's dad hadn't been happy. It was one of the few times he ever paid you any attention. "Sooooo.... instrument?"

"Yeah, don't know what yet, but... I don't know. Something to let me relax. For at least a little bit. What about you?"

You shrugged. "I dunno, I haven't really thought about it. Your dad bought a bunch of skirts, so I might be stuck with those whenever I can't find any jeans. Can I try for track or volleyball or something?"

She considers. "...Why not. It'd look good on paper if you keep it up until the end of high school."

Ugh. She always had to think far into the future. You never got why. This problem will be over soon enough.

"We're gonna be in different classes this year, you know."

You rolled your eyes. "I'm aware, yeah."

"So I can't keep track of you."

You raised an eyebrow. "Track of me?"

"Oh, don't be coy. Just keep out of trouble. Is that so hard?"

You shrugged non-committally. "I won't break a nail." You frowned thoughtfully. "Hey, did you know breaking a nail actually hurts? It really pokes at you. Moves make it seem so petty, but its kind of a huge pain."

"Really? I haven't had a long nail since this all star- no, dammit,stop distracting me." She grabbed your shoulders. "Stay. Out. Of trouble. Can you handle that?"

You pushed her off. "Fine, fine, don't be such a worrywart. I got it."

And so began your middle school career. The two of you in separate classes, with separate people and separate possibilities, and the increasingly likely concern that this forever body swap really was forever.

But it shouldn't be too bad. Right?
1431132212112.title: Skip to middle school

choices: The guy was bullying some other kid
To be honest, you started this one
14311322121121.content:
You began your first day at Riverbank Middle School, so named for the river that cut its way through the end of the district. On paper, it might sound peaceful or tranquil to pass by the river on your way to school each day. In practice, it was dirty and gross to look at, polluted by various trash or even just the natural remains of nature sullying the waters.

Still. Its nice to see the ducks.

You enter the school wearing a nice blouse and a skirt. Emily's dad insisted for your first day. The only times he really seemed to pay attention was when "his little girl" wasn't dressing "right". To be honest, you had a theory that Emily's princess room was something she enjoyed mostly because it had to be one of the few things he really doted on her with. But you didn't want any hassle and there is something nice about seeing him smile as you leave. So, you go to school wearing the stupid things.

Almost immediately, you notice how much bigger the school is. In sixth grade, your elementary school was starting to feel like you were a giant in a tiny doll house. Now? Two floors, over a larger distance, with hundreds more kids in one building. The smell of hormones replaced glue and paint. God, you thought high school was the one where teens went wild, but suddenly you got the impression that middle school might be a bit different than what you expected. Boys wore jerseys, girls wore shorter shorts, and there wasn't a single goofy child's doodle pasted onto a wall. Lockers to decorate, banners on walls, and much much more. You were really growing up.

Of course, there was always going to be some jackass who hadn't gotten the memo about being mature for once. Such as the slimy Joey Duncan, chatting ahead of you with some other students in the halls.
14311322121121.title: You get into a fight with a boy on the first day

choices: You quickly get overwhelmed by Joey's crew
143113221211211.content:
Distracted by your surroundings, you barely caught Joey's conversations with his pals.

"This is like a whole new world, man. The school's our oyster, with all sorts of treats to explore."

You didn't pay much heed to the squawking and laughing of the dudes. You had better things to do than to pay attention to what random people were chatting about.

That all quickly dived out the window when you felt a hand on your ass. You flipped around quick, glaring daggers at Joey. The best just waved smugly as he and his cronies guffawed amongst themselves.

"What the hell was that?!"

"Just sharing the love, babe." He retorted with a wink. "You're sharing the beauty, after all."

Was that supposed to be charming and not slimy as hell? "Touch me again? You don't get that hand back."

The crew laughed again in surprise. "Oooooohhhh, spunky!" Joey placed a hand on the locker, leaning in close into your space. "If you're looking to be spunky, I can think of a few places we could go real wide at.

It was at that point you slammed his head into the lockers. Before he or his cronies could react, you grabbed his head again and brought it down onto your knees.

Joey tumbled to the ground, nose and jaw bleeding already. "What the hell, you bitch?!"

"Are you really supposed to be a middle schooler? It's time to grow up!"
143113221211211.title: Joey harassed you

1431132212112112.content:
Before his lackeys could join in (or even better, you getting in a couple more hits), an older man with a long mustache grabbed your arm.

"That's enough! For Christ's sake, it's the first damn day of school. Get the nurse's office, kid."

You were about to assure him that you were fine, you realized he was pointing at Joey.

"Wait, hold on!"

"Settle down, missy."

"But he was the one that-"

"Yeah yeah."

No matter what you said, the teacher had no interest in listening. You could only wait as you were dragged to the principal's office.
1431132212112112.title: A teacher steps in

choices: Emily's mom approves of your actions
Emily's dad is gonna be in a mood
14311322121121121.content:
Emily's father was, once again, busy. Or perhaps he couldn't stand the idea of his precious little girl that he never paid attention to doing anything bad and avoided the whole event. Emily's mom didn't arrive for several hours, leaving you in the principal's office for an extended amount of time. He had already lectured you at length for the fight, then he lectured you at length for the delay in your parents arrival and how it was cutting into your class time. Then he assigned you busywork to do in the administration office while he did other work. You could only stare at math problems as the students shuffling through the halls walked by, occasionally glancing and laughing at the girl who got in trouble on her first day.

You'd been in the school for ten minutes and now everyone thought Emily Williams was a thug. Awesome.

Eventually, Emily's mom shuffled in, dressed in surprisingly fancy clothes. You frowned in confusion. You'd seen that dress before. That was the fancy "impress someone" dress Mrs. Williams wore for special occasions. Did this count as a special occasion? She could be trying to impress the principal? That'd make sense.

...Or maybe she was already out and about today. But that would be insane: unless she brought them with, that would mean she left the twin toddlers home alone for hours.

"Are Ethan and Sophie in the car?"

She glared down at you, with eyes that screamed Don't try to distract me.

Sensing the aura of an angry suburban mom, the secretary buzzed the two of you into the office. Some polite introductions:

"Welcome Mrs. Williams."

"Please, call me Lorraine."

The politeness wasn't meant for you and you were quickly targeted for another round of lectures. The principal listed all the various amount of trouble you were in, attacking a defenseless student who just so happened to be the son of someone on the school board. You attempted to defend yourself, pointing out that he really started it, but that quickly got shot down.

Emily's mom stayed quiet throughout the conversation, simply nodding at various points. You were only sure she was listening when she talked about punishment with the principal. Detention was the bare minimum here and she of course assured there would be some punishment at home "to be determined." Hands were shaken and you were shoved out of the school into "your" mom's hands for the rest of the day.

The two of you trudged towards the car in silence, surrounded by the sweltering heat of the pre-fall weather. The car was a Taurus, cheap and falling apart but efficient enough for travel. Ethan and Sophie were definitely not in the car.

You opened up the side door to see a long Men's button shirt splayed on the seat. You didn't recognize it. Was it Emily's dad's? No, that didn't seem right.

"Get in already." Emily's mother quickly scolded, tossing the shirt into the back.

You sat down quickly and buckled up. Within seconds, the car was rolling down the afternoon streets and a tension in the air that was downright suffocating.
14311322121121121.title: Parent Teacher Lectures

143113221211211211.content:
Eventually, the two of you reached your destination. You kept your eyes on the floor of the Taurus, terrified to look up. You were gonna get whipped. You just knew it.

A crackly voice interrupted your thoughts.

"Welcome to Dairy Queen, can I take your order?"

Your head shot up to discover that the two of you had, sure enough, arrived at a fast food joint.

"Yes, uh, one mini Strawberry Blizzard annnnnnd..." She turned to you. "What do you want, Emily?"

Your mouth opened and shut like a fish. Eventually you managed: "...a medium Oreo Blizzard?"

She nodded and turned back to the fast food radio.... thing. You didn't know the word and you sure weren't about to think too hard about it now. "And a medium Oreo Blizzard."

Emily's mom drove through the various stops of the Dairy Queen, handed over her card, and passed you the Oreo Blizzard before pulling out of the drive through.

You could only stare at it in confusion. Was it poisoned or something?

"Hurry up. It'll melt."

You glanced between her and the Blizzard.

"...Am I in trouble?"

She blinked in surprise before smiling sadly. "No, you're alright, dear."

This was the weirdest shit ever.

"I mean.... I did slam Joey into a locker. He told you that, right? I slammed him right into a locker."

She laughed, a sound you hadn't heard from Mrs. Williams ever. "And defended yourself from a complete menace, it sounded like."

"And you're... rewarding me?"

She sighed. "Honey, it's a tough world out there. Standing up to people like that is hard for a lot of people. But somehow, it came to you naturally."

She idly fixed your hair. "I'm proud of you, Emily."

You blushed, feeling a surprise lightness in your body. That felt good. You haven't felt that good in a while.

Feeling brave, you decided to venture forward.

"Mom, can I ask you something?"

"Fire away."

"Are things... alright with dad?"

She looked offended for a moment before stuffing down the feeling. "What makes you say that?"

You glanced at the shirt in the back. "Just a thought."

She drug a hand through her hair and sighed. "Things are... tense right now. It's hard not to get frustrated when he's not home. When he comes home late every single night and barely talks to any of us when he does. So... mommy's trying some stuff for herself for now."

You think you understood. "Okay." You hesitate. "Thanks for telling me."

"No problem, sweetie. And if anything else goes wrong and you need help? I'm here."

You don't know if that's true. She's been pretty lax so far, especially with Ethan and Sophie.

But for right now? Emily's mom actually feel like she's your mom. And you feel like cherishing this feeling of validation and support while you can.
143113221211211211.title: Mother's Love

143113221211211212.content:
You let the silence sit for several minutes. It was overwhelming in its oppressive presence in the air but you couldn't bear the idea of breaking it yourself. Luckily, Emily's mother was more than happy to smash that barrier.

"I can't believe, you. How could you be so completely stupid?" She huffed. "And on your first goddamn day. That's just great. When did you go from the smartest girl in school to a snot-nosed whiner?"

"He grabbed my ass." You retorted.

"Language!"

"Its what happened!"

"I don't care how it happened, language!" The car reached a stoplight and she took the time to glare at you fully. "For god's sake, Emily. Did you even think about how this will affect me? They're gonna think I'm some kind of deadbeat mom. Is that what you wanted? Hm?"

You grimaced and turned toward the window. Whatever. Its not like she was your real mom anyway.

...Real family.

"Who's shirt is that?" You finally interrupt the lecture. You aren't looking at her but you can feel the confusion in the air.

"What?"

"Its not dad's shirt. But its not yours either. So who's using it? Why's it in your car?"

The car screeched to a sudden halt, your body flinging forward until stopped by by the pull of the seat belt. Before you could even recover from the stop, Emily's mom grabbed your arm harshly, digging her sharp nails into your skin.

"Don't you give me that smart fucking mouth, missy!" You tried to pull away but you were stuck in the grasp of her hand and her hateful glare. "If you're so goddamn smart, you wouldn't be acting like a thug."

You didn't know what to say, mouth desperately moving but not coming up with anything substantial to retort with. The sounds of honking cars echoed behind the two of you and this seemed to be the only thing that forced the woman to released your arm and continue the drive. You took the opportunity to try and soothe the pain in you arm, while Mrs. Williams fumed to herself.

"You need to learn to behave. You clearly didn't learn any manners in elementary school. Just how to be uppity and rude."

She turned to you again. "If you don't shape up, we're sending you to a private school."

You felt your blood go cold. "What?"

"Ohhh, so that gets your attention?" She grinned smugly. "Can't be bothered to pay attention to me before, but now she listens."

"M-mom, I can't go to a private school!" If you were away in private, you'd be away from Emily. Then you'd never be able to figure out how to switch back.

"Can't isn't what I want to hear. I want to hear won't. Because you'll behave and you won't cause me any trouble."

"Mom, if I'm gone, who's going to take care of Ethan and Sophie?!"

She glared again. "So, what, you think I'm not pulling my weight? That I'm not taking care of them?!"

"You left them at home alone!"

She shoved a pointy, painted finger at your face. "One more screw-up at school and any more of that back-talk? You're going to that school. Where you'll learn courtesy and rules. Things that, despite what you clearly think, do apply to you!"

You shut your mouth mid-retort, descending into the seat in shock. Mrs. Williams' had a face that radiated pure smug delight. "Now, what do we say?"

"....I'll behave."

"I'll behave, what?"

You grit your teeth together. "I'll behave, ma'am."

She pinched your cheek. "That's my girl."
143113221211211212.title: Parental Disapproval

choices: Trying to keep the peace at school
Failing to keep the peace at school
1431132212112112122.content:
"What the hell were you thinking?!"

You were at the playground again. You sit on a swing set, twirling idly and staring at the ground as you received what had to be your eighth lecture this week. Emily stomped back and forth in front of you, smoke practically bursting out her ears.

"One day! One day alone! That's all you had to do! But you couldn't even manage that!" Her arms couldn't decide whether to be folded up or thrown in the air. "And what if you get sent to this school, whatever it is? That'll be on my permanent record! I'll never get good grades, I'll never get into Harvard, and I'll never get that law degree!"

You pinched the bridge of your nose. "Yes, your poor future, how tragic."

"Is this funny to you?!" She grabbed the front of your shirt, eyes ablaze. "That's my body you're messing with! My life, my world! And it's-" She was getting choked up, but she shoved the emotion down. She was focused on the anger. "It's all tumbling down the drain!"

"So what?!" You fired back, slapping away her hand. "That's your body Joey was lusting after! You'd rather I let him think you were a piece of meat?!"

She rolled her eyes. "I've met him. He's just a dude. You probably egged him on somehow. Maybe if you had worn something else, this wouldn't have even happened."

Time froze as you processed the words. She was blaming you. She was literally, actually blaming you for this. The frustration with seeing her body in this position? You could understand that. But she was actually, factually blaming you for a boy's advances.

You laughed, unable to hold back at the absurdity of it all.

"What the hell's so funny?!"

You stood up and walked away, shaking your head. "You wouldn't get it, Em. You're too far gone."

"What's that supposed to mean?" But whatever else she had to say didn't matter.

You had agonized about your slow steps into girlhood. You cringed at make-up, you cringed at skirts, and you cringed at the getting called "cute." You got used to each step and you despaired at how you got used to it. You feared losing yourself to being a girl, even as it wasn't as bad as you thought.

And here was Emily, in your body, telling a girl she should've worn something different to avoid getting harassed by a pervert.

While you were getting used to being a girl, she was getting used to being a boy.

Would youhave been like that? You'd like to think not but it was hard to say.

You looked back at Emily. She- He was staring at you in utter confusion. He really didn't get it. Maybe he never would.

Well, if you were going to be a girl, you might as well be proud that you were smarter than a dumb boy.
1431132212112112122.title: Gender Dynamics at Play

choices: You're sent to a fancy, but strict, girl's finishing school
You're sent to a crumbling, cheap school for bad girls
14311322121121121222.content:
You had to admit. Once you stopped caring about Emily's feelings, your life at school got a lot easier.

Which isn't to say life wasn't still soul-crushing and full of bullying and isolation. No, that was just standard middle school stuff. But now? You didn't care about Emily's stupid future. Screw Emily's future! You were in the present and the world of the present said that it was time to focus on making sure everyone knew you weren't to be messed with. If anybody looked at you weird? Stand up to them. Anybody gave you attitude? You threw it back at them. Someone attacked you? You gave them twice as much of a beating. Within a few days, you were the punk girl at school who wore nice blouses and cute skirts.

And you were loving it.

You lasted a few weeks before the teachers eventually caught you in the act. Teachers were called, decisions were made, and you were being shipped off hundreds of miles away.

The only ones who took it hard was Ethan and Sophie. They weren't old enough to know what was going on, but they knew they weren't going to see their big sis for a while. They grabbed onto your legs, trying to desperately stop you from leaving.

"Stay! Sis gotta stay!"

"Guys, come on, mom and dad are gonna be pissed."

"No piss! Just stay!"

The tug-of-war continued for a while until you finally sat down next to the young ones.

"I'll be back soon, okay? I'm just gonna be gone for a few months. I'll be back for Christmas."

Their ears perked at the name drop of a holiday. "Chrissmiss sis?"

You ruffled Ethan's hair. "Yeah. Christmas sis."

"Sis stay!" Sophie piped in again.

"For Christmas. For now, I gotta go. But I'll be back, I promise."

They didn't really understand a word. But the tone seemed to appease them, even if their tears didn't stop as you were shuffled off into Mr. Williams' car.

So this was it. You were off to some whole new set-up, where you could be yourself for at least a little bit.... or they could shove ideas into your head about what kind of person you should be.

This was gonna suck.
14311322121121121222.title: Getting sent to a new school

choices: The principal immediately takes a dislike to you
143113221211211212221.content:
Agatha Willard's Academy for Young Girls, a school focused on raising girls "right and proper." You can only assume Agatha was some stuffy old woman from the 1920s, as the advertisements boast ensuring that girls leave the Academy with manners, respect, and a variety of useful skills. For an admittedly steep price, girls from all over the country could learn to enter the world with grace and prestige.

Mr. Williams dropped you off at the fancy, polished gates of the academy with your suitcase and nary a word. Not even a good bye. Keeping your cool, you step through the gates, passing by a gardener watering the flowers lined along the brick barrier between you and the outside world.

It was a nice looking institution, you had to admit. Girls in uniforms walked to their classes next to bright green lawns. The buildings and lawn were carefully maintained. You could see a decent track field in the distance and from the outside, the dorm room building looked immaculate. Entering the main building, the floors were nicely polished and glass cases of awards and trophies lined the walls.

The size of the campus, and the size of the girls' textbooks, left you feeling pretty overwhelmed already. Some of the girls were giving you noticeable looks and you had a hard time deciphering if they were good looks or bad.

You finally found your way to the main office, where a secretary simply pointed to a chair as she yammered away on the phone. You sludged over to the seat hesitantly, fidgeting as the minutes dragged on, staring at the principal's door.

New school. New people. New expectations to live up to. Oh boy.
143113221211211212221.title: Willard's Academy for Young Girls

1431132212112112122211.content:
Eventually, the door labeled "Principal Staunch" opened wide and a middle-aged woman with a long nose and a stern gaze glared down at you.

"Miss Williams, correct? Do step inside."

With a sensation that this was going to be a stressful beginning, you move from the lobby to the nice office of the woman. It was a finely polished and organized room, with various plagues and commerative photos literred on the walls and desks. Pictures of grateful parents and smiling children. A framed newspaper clipping praising the school. A large portrait of another, even older looking woman. You could only imagine that one was of Agatha Willard herself on the wall.

The principal sat behind a wooden desk, organizing a file carefully. She gestured to a chair behind you. "Sit."

You did so, yet she still huffed in annoyance.

"So, Miss Williams. You've gotten yourself into some trouble lately."

You nod slowly. "A bit, I suppose."

"You suppose." The dryness in her tone felt like it came from the desert. "You suppose that constant fights for several months could be called some trouble?"

"...Yeah."

She huffs again, closing the file. "And what do you "suppose" is the cause of that trouble, hm? Your file describes you as a good student initially yet you suddenly slides into delinquency. Are you going to blame issues at home? Bullying at school? Unfair treatment? Exerting frustration for some perceived slight upon your life?"

You really shouldn't sass, but your annoyance with this woman was reaching its apex. "Well, I could tell you about my whole body swap situation and how fighting makes me feel like myself in a different life."

"Oh, how hysterical, Miss Williams. What a comedian you could be." Staunch stood up, moving around her desk. "You know what I think, Miss Williams? I think you are just naturally a bad person. I think you enjoy being a rude little thing and you want to see how long you can get away with it. Does that sound accurate?"

You swallow. "Kinda sounds like some premature judgment I guess."

"And more attitude. What a naughty little girl you are, Miss Williams. Why I do believe you are one of the naughtier girls I've ever met! Tell me, Williams, why should I bother with a naughty girl like you?"

"Uhhhh... I don't kno-"

"Because it's my calling!" She paced around her desk. "Ensuring naughty little children like you learn how to behave in the real world is what I've spent my whole life accomplishing. And like many girls before you, I will have your naughty little nature squeezed out into you've become a proper young lady."

"Could you... please stop saying naughty? It's getting kind of uncomfortable."

She gave you another glare. "Room 212 in the dorms. You'll meet your roommate there. I'll be watching you constantly Williams. So you better not be up to any funny business. Behave."

You nod quickly, retrieving the key from Staunch's handand escaping back out to campus. This was already immensely creepy and you hadn't been here gen minutes. What other brand of Weird would you have to deal with today?

Oh right. A roommate.
1431132212112112122211.title: The principal immediately takes a dislike to you

14311322121121121222111.content:
It didn't take long to trudge your bag across campus towards the dorms. The other girls (girls not "other" girls, you tried to remind yourself) giggled at the sight when they thought you couldn't hear them. You weren't particularly looking forward to settling in here.

A quick ride up the elevator took you to your designated floor. You soon reached the door that housed your new roommate. A whiteboard hung next to the room number, with little doodles of flowers and some generic quote of inspiration. You sighed. Well, I guess I'll take generic over wild. Fiddling with the key, you quietly entered.

The room itself was supremely organized. Not a spec of dust or dirty clothes sat on the floor. A single pair of shoes sat under one of the beds. On the other side was a hamper which, from your position, even seemed to have clothes folded inside it.

At the end of the room were two desks. Sitting at one was the cleanliness queen herself, typing away at her computer. She turned at your entry, pushing away from the desk, and smiled an almost obnoxiously large smile.

"Oh, you must be Emily! I got a message that you would be arriving soon."

Warily, you nodded. "That's right. And you're Glori-"

Before you could finish, she grabbed your hand and shook it rigorously. "Gloria Stein. Oh, I'm sure we'll get along great! Let me show you around."

She quickly whisked you around the room, showing off her schedule, her charts, where she put all of her homework when she finished, the hamper, the closet, etc etc. You weren't sure how long it took, her mouth moving too fast for you to process the the time surrounding it.

Eventually, she lowered her voice to a whisper, bringing you closer. "I should warn you- there's a lot of girls on this floor who used to be troublemakers. Some of them are better now but I really don't think you can just trust anyone who used to do that sort of thing. Don't you agree?"

A bead of sweat trails down your face. "I... guess it depends on the person for me. I don't want to judge people."

She smiles a condescending smile. "Its good to have that sort of faith. But you really should be careful. Like, across the hall? That's Vivian Brown. She's almost certainly a nuisance waiting to happen. You can smell the cigarettes on her. And her uniform?" She pulled you in a few inches closer. "She shortened it a few inches. I can tell."

"That does sound like... something."

The wonderful thing about vague comments is that the listener can interpret it anyway they desired. Gloria seemed particularly satisfied with your response. "I almost feel bad for her roommate. Jenny is a bit of a space case so she no doubt gets dragged into all sorts of nonsense."

Pulling back, she smiled once more. "But no worries. As long as you stick with me, I'm sure we can steer you on a good path."

You strained to plaster a smile on your face. "Glad to hear it."

---------------------

The academy wasted little time dropping you right into its studies. Teachers quickly gave you work assignments that failed to catch you up on the lessons you had already missed. Very little sympathy was offered for your confusion. You were pretty much expected to just get right to business.

Even if she was a bit overenthusiastic, you couldn't deny that Gloria was helpful. She offered some advice and tried to help you catch up on what details the teachers expected you to take for granted. Still, you weren't entirely sure yet if this was a person you wanted to befriend in the long-term.

You had run into your neighbors in the meantime. Vivian certainly stood out. She was one of the few students who had dyed her hair, a dark purple, against official school policy. She often wore a black leather jacket over her uniform. And you couldn't deny that the skirt did seem a little small on her. You couldn't deny, given your recent experiences with authority, there was something delightful about her general apathy towards anything an adult said to her.

By comparison, Jennifer Fritz nearly flew past your radar. She was one of those people it was easy to let your eyes drift past. Her dreamy expressions were almost hidden behind her glasses and freckled face. At least her short hair made it easy to see her.

About a week into your stay at Willard's, you hadn't done much yet to engage with many of the girls. You were still a teen boy in here after all. It was hard enough handling the locker rooms, much less making conversation. You weren't even sure what a lot of them thought of you.

But, having finally caught up enough to enjoy your lunch in somewhere other than the studyroom, maybe this was the time to do it. You entered the cafeteria, grabbing some surprisingly delicious food, and gazed over the tables. Gloria and a small posse of other girls had a table with a few free spaces. On the other hand, Jen was doodling in her notebook at a table all on her own. It might be nice to sit with someone quiet.

Yet, just outside the window and at the outside tables, you could spy Vivian kicking back with her own meal, fiddling with some smokes. It was hard to deny, she seemed pretty interesting. But you could only imagine Gloria getting huffy about associating with her. Did you really want that to deal with?
14311322121121121222111.title: Gloria Stein: the teacher's pet

choices: ... and slowly start to find your place in the clique.
... while you and Gloria drift away from the lunch table.
... and you try to distance yourself from Gloria and the rest.
143113221211211212221111.content:
You decide to play it safe and just eat with Gloria. Despite all her talk about 'good paths' and disconcerting concern with uniform length, she didn’t seem like a bad person. At least, not entirely. In any case, it didn't feel like a good idea to piss off your teacher's pet of a roommate by eating with Vivian.

You take your plate of lamb ragout and whipped potatoes — surprisingly nice for a school lunch — and plop yourself next to Gloria wordlessly. At once, all the coiffed heads at the table turn to you, and the pit of unease sinks deeper in your stomach.

Almost every face presents a different brand of disdain: some with the wide eyes of bemusement, others with lip curl of disgust, and others with a raised eyebrow of amusement. Only Gloria seemed to meet you with a friendly smile, shifting her tray slightly to accommodate yours.

You pick at your food for a few minutes as the table’s attention seems to drift away from the ‘new girl’ and back to whatever they were before you sat down. It wasn’t really that bad sitting here, you guess. A spike of anxiety and then it’s over. Like ripping off a bandaid.

You’ve nearly nibbled your way through your meal drama-free when a hand alights itself upon your shoulder. You turn to the hand’s owner — Gloria, of course — half-anticipating some sanctimonious lecture.

“Everything, alright, Emily? You’re not talking much.”

You force a half-smile to your face and wave a mollifying hand. “Yeah, everything’s alright, it’s just nerves. New stuff, you know?”

Gloria’s concerned expression melts into a mask of empathy with no small amount of pity. “Oh you poor thing. Don’t worry, I’ll make sure you’re only surrounded by the most helpful people here.”

She squeezes your shoulder semi-comfortingly, surreptitiously squirts a bit of hand sanitizer into her hands, and goes back to eating her food with a self-satisfied smile.

Huh. That was the first mostly-positive interaction you’ve had with Gloria and it was… nice? Sure, she may be a little pretentious, but her heart was… close to the right place. Maybe being roommates wouldn’t be tha—

A sudden ting breaks the ambient noise of quiet chattering and clinking forks. Everyone at the table — and a few girls from neighboring ones — turn their heads curiously to the source of the noise. You follow suit, only differing by the expression of sheer dread on your face.

Gloria has stood up next to you, a glass of water in one hand and salad fork in the other. You plead with your eyes for her to please sit down, but she receives your venom with a smile.

She inclines a finger at you, and the number of faces meeting yours make you want to shrink down into your seat.

“Everyone, this is my roommate, Emily!”

Their faces are smooth, impassive masks. You wish you could make your shaky awkward smile match theirs.

"She’s new, so she’s a bit nervous, of course, so be sure to be extra nice to her.”

Smiles break out on some of the faces. They run the gamut from simpering to barely-contained-mirth, but none of them look particularly genial.

“And, of course, help her out loads so she doesn’t have to associate with… troublemakers.”

She gazes pointedly at Vivian, who looks back at her — oh god, and you — with an expression of pure disgust.

“In summation, I want you to treat her as you would any one of us. That’s all.”

She sits down with the same smug smile as before and silence reigns through the cafeteria. You keep your gaze fixated on your near-white plate, waiting for… you dunno, laughter? General mockery?

“So, um, Emily? Uh, how’d you get your hair like that?”

You look up in surprise. The voice came from across the table, from a girl with equally blonde hair. You run a hand through a lock absentmindedly.

“Ah, I just brushed it a bunch after I woke up.”

She blinks in bemusement. “Oh. I have to use a ton of conditioner to get it like yours. Mine tangles easily, you know?”

You give a silent nod and put both hands on your tray, ready to leave. You’ve had enough discomfort for the rest of the year, let alone a lunch s—

“Did you dye it?”

You try to not let your consternation show as you answer her question — and then the twenty other ones shot at you by your fellow table members.

~~~


After the ‘cafeteria incident’, your reputation is - to your horror - solidified. Getting in sight range of Vivian means you’re in withering-glare-range. Even the easygoing Fritz keeps her distance from you, eyeing you nervously in the halls.

That, you learn, is thanks to the wonderful reputation of your (apparently, permanent, to your dismay) lunch table. They’re the cattiest clique in the school: most snippets of conversation that you catch are either scathing remarks on another student or an exchange of insipid compliments.

Surprisingly, Gloria is your island away from these inane conversations. She certainly harps on about ‘proper behavior’ and ‘behaving as Agatha Willard would’, but the worst impression she can have of someone is ‘rule-breaker’.

It’s both confusing and relieving that she’s managed to garner a decent amount of respect at the lunch table, but you don’t question it much, especially since a good deal of that social shield covers you. She’s your (relative) island in the sea that you’ve found yourself in, and she’s a decent tutor when you get down to it.

Days come and pass, and lunches go along with them, and you slowly fall into the routine of school life...
143113221211211212221111.title: Eat efficiently with Gloria

143113221211211212221113.content:
The safest choice was Jennifer by far. No drama either end of the spectrum there.

"Mind if I sit here?"

Jennifer glanced up vaguely, fixing you with a quiet, unsettling stare. Just when you thought you should leave, she waves a hand. "Feel free. No one owns space."

You sit down quickly, eager to eat the surprisingly nice food offerings. The benefits of a rich school, you suppose.

As you ate, you started to feel Jennifer's eyes on you. You glance up, and sure enough her glasses were squarely focused on you.

"Is something wrong?"

"Oh yes. Your aura is all off."

"My... aura?" You already felt dread on your spine.

"So angry and mixed up... it's not like any of the girls around here. You must be so troubled."

You didn't know how quite to respond. You looked for an escape and spied the books next to her.

"Uhhhh... whatcha reading?"

"Hm? Oh- Investigations of the Inner Mind. It's about the spiritual center of our brains- the part that connects to spirits."

Yep. A total space case with a side of hippie and wannabe paranormal investigation. Perhaps this wasn't the quiet, unassuming table you were hoping for.

"Sounds... interesting."

"It is. It might be able to explain your mysterious aura."

You tried to return your focus to your food.

-----------------------------------

Despite your best efforts, it seems Fritz latched on quick. She walked alongside you in the halls, furiously scribbling notes about "your condition." You tried to sell her on excuses like "maybe it's just the stress of moving and dealing with strange people." She didn't seem to catch the hint.

The months went on and so did the lunches. This was most definitely a girl's school: one lunch with Fritz was enough to get you barred from the other tables and cliques in school. Gloria quickly lost interest in helping you out. Surprisingly enough, Fritz turned out to be smarter in the regular classes than you gave her credit. She was a handy tutor when you needed the help.

Still, you felt like there was something more you should do as your school year slipped away...
143113221211211212221113.title: My Lunch with Fritz

1431132212112112122211133.content:
Time passes quick. Christmas visits were tolerable with your- Emily's family. Ethan and Sophie were growing ever more slowly. A little brattier too, but still utterly adoring towards their "big sis".

Before you knew it, you and Jen were 16, studying for finals. You cracked your joints, trying to bring any sense of feeling back into your body.

"This suuucks. There's got to be a better use of our time."

"Time is an illusion." And oft-repeated phrase by Jen. "But sadly, finals are not."

"C'mon, Jen. We're young and we're wasting away studying stuff we're never gonna actually need to know. I want to live."

She smiled a dreamy smile. "You always say that, but there's nothing that ever suits your dreams."

You flop to the other side of her bed. "You must have overheard Viv mention any cool parties in town. Anything."

She gazed off towards nowhere. "I suppose there was some sort of wild gathering at the Riot House later tonight."

"You could definitely get Viv to get us inside for that! You've done enough of her work for her for it."

"That's not really my scene...." Her eyes lit up. "Oh! But I think I've finally found a possible source of your strange aura!"

Uggghhhh. You had hoped she finally dropped that. "It's been years, Jen, isn't it time to throw in the towel."

"Finding your place in the universe can be just as fun and enlightening as teen parties."

"So you're saying you'd be willing to go to one."

Her lips frowned a fraction. "I suppose, if you insist."

Ohhhh a party could be just what you needed. But on the other hand, Jen and you had stuck together for this long. It could be nice to indulge her a little.
1431132212112112122211133.title: Skip Ahead More Years

choices: The concoction makes you more like Emily
It makes you more like another student
14311322121121121222111332.content:
Ahhhh, it wasn't like Viv would actually let strangers hitch a ride to the club anyway.

"Fine, if you're dead set on it, investigate away."

Her dreamy eyes lit up with glee. "I knew you'd come around, Emily."

She bounced over to her desk, pulling out her book of notes. "Now, it seems to me that the problem with your aura is that it's a mix of different kinds. It should be one color most of the time, but it's changing so frequently. I think it means your soul is both comfortable and uncomfortable in its container."

"Sure, Jen." You tried to keep off the harshest of your sarcasm.

"This is probably tied to some strange event in your childhood. Something that would make you not feel right in your own skin?"

You tried not to tense. Okay, this was getting a little real.

"Probably something very supernatural. You could have been touched by a spirit, or some passing entity decided to pull a prank or cast a spell on your very center."

You leaned up from the bed. "Erm. I don't suppose there's a way to balance my aura in any way? Or undo whatever this... spirit did?"

"Oh, it'd be very hard to get the proper materials to undo it. Spells and curses are hard on your soul, and it's been so long that it could be tied too deep to your soul to fix it."

Your shoulders slumped. "What about this... soul balance thing?"

"Oh, well, with the right ingredients, you could change your aura to fit a different hue. It's quite an exhilarating experience, I hear."

You didn't really understand this mumbo jumbo, but it sounded like you could maybe find a way out of this stupid body. "Hey, we got time, I say we try that!"

"Really? You've never been interested in spiritual practices before."

"Hey, you said exhilarating. I'm up for exhilaration."

"Well, that's all fine with me!"

And she swiftly got to work, mixing together herbs and spices into cans and bottles.

Perhaps, if you paid more attention to her words over the years, you'd understand that Jen wasn't proposing removing the soul from the body. She was suggesting altering the soul to better fit the body.

But you didn't listen to lessons in general. You were a just a teenage girl now, after all.
14311322121121121222111332.title: Spiritual Happenings

143113221211211212221113323.content:
"Emily, I'm not sure you really understand what this does..."

You wave off Jen's worrying. "It's all about fixing my aura, right? Then let's do it to it! Aura me up!"

She didn't take much convincing, handing over a small bottle of herbs. "Before you go to bed, take one of these. Oh, and say 'My old aura is through, let my soul renew. Oh-and make sure you have a strand of your hair underneath your pillow, wrapped in one of these leaves-"

"I got it!" You were too excited to focus on details. Tomorrow, you'd be a new you and out of this crummy body. You didn't waste any time completing the instructions and heading off to bed.

And as you slept, the magic of the herbs got to work flowing into your head.

What sort of person did you become?
143113221211211212221113323.title: Personality Changes

1431132212112112122211133233.content: maybe tomboyish but at least you start to accept to be a girl
1431132212112112122211133233.title: Someone else

14311322121121121222111332331.content:
Waking up felt... different in the morning. It was hard to describe. A lightness that wasn't there before. A weight vanished.

Crawling out of bed, you trudged your way to the mirror. You blinked thoughtfully at it. The reflection blinked back.

Yep. Still a girl.

Oh well, you gave it a good ol' college try. And that's all you could really do sometimes. There was no use getting upset over failure- sometimes you could do everything right and still fail. And that's okay!

You stretched back, fluffing your hair a little. It was getting a bit long. You usually cut it around now. Hairdressers always recoiled at cutting it too short, so you stuck with as short as they'd allow. But actually, you found you didn't quite mind long hair as much as usual. In fact, maybe it was time to finally do something with it. Nothing fancy, of course. Just long enough to work into a ponytail. You nodded, smiling. That would be a good compromise.

Borrowing some of Gloria's make-up, you freshened yourself up a bit. Again, nothing crazy. It just got so annoying when people said you looked tired and pale. Just a light blush would do the trick. That was much nicer.

Satisfied, you quickly assembled your uniform. That was still a pain. How were you supposed to really stretch your legs in a skirt? Maybe you could get away with putting shorts on underneath....?

But that was a problem for another day. Once you were all put together, you strolled out to the great wide world to prepare for a brand new day.

Jen almost seemed startled to see you in the cafeteria hall. "Emily? Are... you feeling alright?"

"Hm? Yeah, why wouldn't I?" You took a bite from an apple. "In fact... I feel better than ever!"

"R-really?"

"Yeah!" You chewed thoughtfully. "Probably too late to join any extracurricular stuff, huh?"

"I... suppose so?"

"Oh well. Always high school!"

Jen blinked after you in confusion. You know, you had to admit.... Emily was a really nice name. You don't know why it bothered you so much before now.
14311322121121121222111332331.title: Tomboy Time

143113221211211212222.content:
Safe Harbor School for Troubled Teens, a pleasant school who's website boasted a therapeutic program for misbehaving kids of all races, genders, and backgrounds. Kids entered Safe Harbor as potential felons and exited as upright members of society.

So claimed their website anyway. You had done your own research and it seemed to you that kids walked into the building and came out with a variety of issues. It wasn't pricey, but it was certainly located in one of those states that happened to have lax laws on child education and protection.

Mr. Williams didn't blink an eye at the crumbling stone wall around the school. Within seconds of removing your bag from the car, he peeled off onto the open road. Considering his general attitude, you wouldn't be surprised if he was still pissy that his perfect daughter was enough of a nuisance that he actually had to pay attention to what went on in the house.

Stepping into the school's campus was like stepping into a prison. The ground was pure pavement, cigarettes littering the area. You could see a few students already who were clearly skipping class. Stepping into the main building introduced filthy floors, a metal detector at the entrance, and suspicion from every single eye around you.

The secretary seemed convinced that you were here for detention and barely listened when you explained that you were new. You were left waiting in the lobby next to the principal's office. You could almost make out someone talking on the other said through the thin walls.

"Well ma'am, injuries happen all the time and I believe the consent forms you signed when you enrolled your son insured that the school could not be held accountable for that accident. Yes, I know he's in rough shape, but I think it's important to ask which of the students started the fight that led to the stabbing. Perhaps your son was more to blame than you think."

Oh no.
143113221211211212222.title: Safe Harbor School for Troubled Teens

choices: Forget make-up and wear whatever you want
Put on make-up and wear whatever you want
Freshen up and put on something just girly enough
14311322121122.content:
You woke up with the all too familiar and annoying sound of a blaring alarm.Ergh. You shoved your head under the pillow, trying to drown out the sound. Couldn't Summer last one more week? Or even just one more day?

You whined and grumbled and tossed and turned, but eventually you forced yourself into an upright position. You slapped the alarm through bleary eyes and shifted off of the bed. The soft feeling of carpet in between your toes was a welcome relief as you shifted your way towards the bathroom, picking up your clothes for the day as you did so. Hopping into the shower, you let the warm water wash all over you.

Concerns about seeing each other's bodies had vanished a long time ago. You knew you were growing and the beginnings of what would clearly become breasts in a few years was forming on your chest. You weren't entirely sure what was going to happen next to your body. You were still a bright blonde, but you knew people who's hair darkened as they got older. But the future was quite literally a problem for another time. At the moment, your concern was washing, drying, and getting to class.

You trudged out onto the kitchen's hard wood floors as Ethan and Sophie scurried around you, playing around with each other. You retrieved the Cheerios from the pantry and made up a breakfast for the three of you. Idly, you consider if you should start waking up earlier. Cheerios might be good for a quick breakfast, but the twins (and you) might need some more protein and fruit.

"Good morning, honey."

You glance in surprise at the plate of toast and eggs before you. Your eyes followed the hairy hand holding the dang thing up to the mustachioed face of Emily's dad. He hadn't ever made breakfast for you before.

"....Morning, dad." You accept the plate reluctantly, shifting to your seat.

"Looking forward to your first day?" An oddly excited tone.

You shrug. "Kind of, I guess. I'm not really sure what to expect."

He ruffles your hair eagerly. "Oh, don't worry about it, honey. My little girl will do just fine."

You strangled a huff. Honestly, you were 12, almost 13! That was practically an adult.

You ate in silence for a while as Ethan and Sophie flung cheerios at each other.

"Is that what you're planning on going out in?" You glance up at Emily's dad, sipping a cup of coffee casually.

"Huh?" You looked down. You weren't wearing anything crazy. In fact, it was pretty conservative. A sweater for the fall chills, jeans, maybe a jacket if necessary. "What's wrong with it?"

"I just think you'd look cute in one of the skirts I bought you."

Ugggggghhhhhhhhh. "I'm sure I'll be fine, dad."

He grimaced, but shrugged. "Just a thought. But make sure to freshen up. You look kind of tired."

Tired? What the heck was that supposed to mean? It was morning, of course you were tired. Your mind wracked for something you were missing. You suppose Emily's mom always spent a lot of time on her appearance each day, putting on make-up and drying her hair and so on. But you weren't really interested in something like that. That was girl stuff, and you were still a boy in here.

After making sure your bags were packed, you started your move out the door. Spotting movement out of the corner of your eye, you reflexively glance to see your reflection staring back at you through the mirror. You pause, taking a moment to soak it in.

Would people really notice that kind of thing? No one would make fun of you for something as small as that, right? What kind of people at school would care about something as stupid as that? Right, of course not.

But you still paused. This was middle school, after all. Things would be different. You couldn't help wondering if you should change something before you go
14311322121122.title: You find yourself facing girl drama

choices: The bullying continues and you eventually snap at her
The bullying continues and you start to break down
143113221211221.content:
Ugh, you didn't have time for this. With a quick goodbye to Ethan and Sophie (you hoped Emily's mom woke up before Emily's dad left, someone had to keep an eye on those two), you strolled out the door and into the new world of school.

You began your first day at Riverbank Middle School, so named for the river that cut its way through the end of the district. On paper, it might sound peaceful or tranquil to pass by the river on your way to school each day. In practice, it was dirty and gross to look at, polluted by various trash or even just the natural remains of nature sullying the waters.

Still. Its nice to see the ducks.

Almost immediately, you notice how much bigger the school is. In sixth grade, your elementary school was starting to feel like you were a giant in a tiny doll house. Now? Two floors, over a larger distance, with hundreds more kids in one building. The smell of hormones replaced glue and paint. God, you thought high school was the one where teens went wild, but suddenly you got the impression that middle school might be a bit different than what you expected. Boys wore jerseys, girls wore shorter shorts, and there wasn't a single goofy child's doodle pasted onto a wall. Lockers to decorate, banners on walls, and much much more. Voices from every direction, students and teens talking amongst themselves excitedly. Everyone was really growing up.

You quickly located your locker and started fishing through your bag for the combination the office had given you. You know you put it in one of these pockets, but where was it...?

As your hand shuffled through the backpack, a notebook spilled out onto the floor and right next to what appeared to be pink high-heeled schools. Your eyes shot up to see another girl in short shorts, a hot pink shirt with the word's "Daddy's Girl" bedazzled on the front, under a white jacket.

You tried not to judge.

"Sorry about that," you apologized quickly, reaching down to pick up the notebook.

A heel stomped down on the paper, tearing on the edges.

"What are youdoing near my locker?" Her voice was haughty and arrogant from the word go. A voice that just encapsulated the sheer aura of someone who had never been told "no."

You glanced between the girl and the lockers. "Uh, well I was given locker 126."

Her mouth curled into a frown. "So I have to be next to some frumpy little potato?"

You stood up sharply, utterly baffled by the words that left her mouth. "Excuse me?"

She pulled on your hair, startling you backward. "I mean, look at this. Are you even using conditioner? And your face. Someone clearly isn't using moisturizer."

Giggling spawned from a few feet away and you turned to see other girls pointedly not looking your way as they covered their clearly grinning mouths.

"What the hell kinda business is yours about my hair?"

The girl shoved your shoulders and you stumbled back several feet. "Well, you've forced everyone to see your droopy little hair and sad little face already, so you've clearly made it my business." She shoved a finger at your chest. "What's the sweater for, sweetie? Covering up a whole lot of nothing?"

You sputtered angrily, too overwhelmed and confused by the insults to come up with anything substantial. And before you could, the girl shoved you aside and continued on her way. "I'll call you if I need someone to make me look even better. Ta!"

You could only stand still in complete befuddlement as other girls giggled around you. What the hell was that? Talking about make-up and her clothes and all that shit? What brought that on? No one had cared about your appearance before now.

...Or maybe they had. You hadn't hung out with a lot of girls (not including Emily) and their lives were always different to yours. They had started caring about fashion and looks and all that junk. You were busy worrying about your lives, thinking about Ethan and Sophie at home. On tv, ads for girls were all about the hottest clothes and the best lipstick. In movies, women were always stunning, with never a hair out of place. You never truly realized that the world thought all that stuff applied to you. Girls were creatures of beauty and you had skipped your way through elementary school without getting too involved in that world.

You picked up you notebook and started shuffling things into the locker, trying not to think about that weird new feeling in your stomach. You had classes to focus on.

1431132212112212.content:
The girl's name was Melissa Jennings, and she was relentless. By the end of the first week, she had built up a posse of similarly mean girls, ready to operate under her command. They had a plethora of targets and you were just another dot on the horizon of insults and rudeness that were hashed out across the school.

You tried to ignore them. You knew you would get in trouble for fighting and you didn't even want to. You didn't even care about your appearance, it was Emily's body! But something about her words really startled to needle at you. You found yourself glancing into the mirror more often, trying to figure out what was wrong with you. Other than the obvious wrong body situation.

You tried making other friends, but nothing was working out. People kept looking at you in weird ways. Girls laughed when they thought you weren't listening. Teachers would stop to ask if you were getting enough sleep, since you didn't look like the other girls in their make-up.

Even Emily herself wasn't any use.

"Look, we talked about this," she tried to explain. "This is middle school. People are gonna talk if a boy and a girl hang out all the time!"

You kept your emotions buried under the surface. "So, what, you're scared people will gossip if we hang out? You'd rather pal around with the boys."

She shrugged helplessly. "I mean, they're gross, but they're not that bad. You're the one who won't make friends with the girls."

They won't talk to me! your mind screams. No one will talk to me! Can't you see I'm all alone?!

"Fine, whatever," you shrug, turning away. "Like I care what you do."

You here her mumble "Douche" under her breath and you feel the pit grow in your stomach

Did they all knew you were different? Could they all just sense you were a boy and wanted you gone? Or maybe you were just....

You hadn't thought much of the idea of girl drama. But you had to remind yourself constantly that's what it was. That it was just girls being catty. That it was entirely on them. They were just words, words that shouldn't even apply to you. But you felt gross. You felt weird, gross, and unwanted.

You trudge home, a month into the school year. You manuever around the twins, you shuffle into your room, and you feel the weight of the overwhelming loneliness all around you.

And you break, collapsing into the bed, tears falling down your cheeks. God, you were crying. Crying. You really were becoming a girl after all. But what was the use? What was the use caring about being manly anymore? You couldn't fight, you couldn't pound out your emotions into a punching bag or a pink-shaped target, or you'd just receive more abuse at school. Your parents didn't know who you were anymore and Emily's parents had little to no interest in any of their kids, much less you. Any outlet for these emotions you once had has been ripped away from you. The only thing that was yours was your tears, and god dammit you were gonna own those tears.

Finally, after an hour, you just stare up at the ceiling, completely drained. There... had to be something you could do. Something to change things. If not at school, at least for you.
1431132212112212.title: The bullying continues and you start to break down

14311322121122122.content:
You couldn't believe you were doing this. It was probably creepy or something, right? But after all the rudeness and snide comments, you had to try something. Anything.

You started with Emily's mom. She seemed like she had to know something about this, right? You approached the room cautiously, peering in on the mother watching tv.

"Hey, uh, mom? Can you-"

"Not now, Emily." She didn't even look at you. "Mommy's busy."

You decided to take what you could out of this old broad and nabbed some supplies from her bathroom before retreating back to your room.

That left your second source: the internet. You weren't exactly surprised by the sheer weight of the online resources available, but it was immediately overwhelming. You didn't even know where to start! Eventually, you managed to track-down some beauty site's "Introduction to Make-Up." Items in bold and colorful fonts sprang at you through the phone browser.

Moisturizer. Melissa mentioned that, right? According to the guide, it had something to do with preventing wrinkles. That didn't really seem like a concern for you right now. Maybe some other time?

Primer There was a primer to make-up? You skimmed the text, reading something about sealing pores and preventing acne. Deciding not to take the risk, you squirt a bit of "Ultra Face Base Primer" into your hand and wipe it around your face.

Foundation seemed important and it was the one you had the most confusion over. You pat the little powder foundation pads with a brush and touched up your face a little. You weren't sure there was much of a different at first, but gradually you began to notice that your face really was starting to seem... smoother.

You went step by step through each material and every instruction, skipping over things that looked superfluous and using whatever seemed useful. You washed your hair, careful not to mess with your work so far, and ldried it according the the instructions. Eyeshadow seemed like a pointless one, but you reluctantly picked a color that didn't seem over the top and applied it carefully. You applied a light blush and almost immediately noticed how much brighter your face looked. It seemed to pop with more life.

Finally, there was the lipstick. You had assumed this would have been the only step at first, not expecting all these details. You tried to find a color that wasn't too noticeable, something that fit the rest of your face. A soft pink hue was pressed against your lips, slowly, with precision and carefully following the guides in front of you.

You took a step back from the mirror to view your work.

A girl looked back. She had curly blonde hair, no longer wild and unbrushed from showers. Her face glowed, with all the little blemishes invisible under the surface of paint that had been carefully applied. Her tired eyes now seem brighter and more awake than they had just minutes ago. What had seemed pale now seemed colorful and full of life.

She looked cute.

You looked cute.

You felt cute.

You rested a hand on your cheek, a smile softly growing. It was hard to believe that was you looking back. Sure, you were a boy and you still wanted to be, honestly, really, but... you couldn't help but feel good, for once, looking like this.

....What else could you do?

You drifted back into your room and into the closet and dresser, picking out clothes you had long ignored. Careful not to destroy your work, you slipped on a skirt and a blouse that, as far as you could tell, seemed to match. You turned back to the mirror and had to take another moment to register it all. A girl in a skirt, looking like she's just found comfort after a long road of suffering.

That was you who looked that sweet.

You twirled around, admiring the swirl of the skirt, the smile in the reflection, the feeling of... happiness. God, you haven't been happy in years and yet some face-paint and a piece of cloth hanging from the waist was actually cheering you up. You had to laugh at the sheer absurdity.

And you did. You laughed loud, for a second, before you tried something softer. A giggle instead of a chuckle. And then you had to giggle at the fact you were giggling and liking the sound and a whole cycle of girlish laughter and amusement sparkled into the air.

There was probably some commentary about gender roles to be had here, but at the moment you couldn't be bothered to care. Being a girl, if it meant feeling like this.... suddenly didn't seem so bad.

You slowly opened your eyes, expecting the bright sun to be beating down on you. Only to find yourself staring up into the stars. Now your mind was turning. Did you really sleep that long? But if you did, why hadn't pool authorities woken you up at closing time?

But then other questions came into your head. if you were staring at the night sky, then where were the recognizable constellations? Big Dipper? Orion? The stars you were staring at seemed to be from a completely different solar system!

Then you took into account what you were laying on. It certainly didn't have the strong, texture of the lounging chairs at the pool. Here, it felt, soft and comfortable. Like a couch or bed. Had you gone home and fallen asleep in front of your tv with a movie on? If so, why didn't you remember?

As you were processing what the Hell was going on, a few strands of blonde hair fell into your vision. You didn't have blonde hair! At least not long enough to get into your face. What happened to you?!

You immediatly sit up, and are greeted by even more discoveries (and even more messy hair in your face). You were currently in what seemed to be a very spacious apartment, but with a very sci-fi feeling to it. With the walls very simple in shape and being mainly white with hints of blue. Mainly lining doorways, also having a very futurisic look. With a large window looking out into the depths of space. Under most circumstances you would be amazed, but you were currently confused, and scared. These feelins only became worse when you took in the changes to your own body!

Rather than looking down at your relatively fit, (but not athletic) body, you were instead staring at a very female, very clearly athletic body, with breasts that while not huge, seemed to reach just passed C-Cup level. Your hips being defined, with mouth watering well toned thighs. Your attire seeming to be an orange leotard with a triangle in the middle, showing a fair amount of clevage, your pants also being pretty tight, leaving little to the imagination. But why did you feel something that clearly wasn't normal hair underneath those mini-shorts?!

"What th-" You immediately clap your slender, but fairly muscular hands over your mouth. You weren't expecting you to really have much from your normal form, but you certainly weren't prepaired for the very feminine voice that came out of your mouth! While it had a pretty tough tone, it was clearly a woman's voice. It kind of sounded familiar too...

But you weren't concerned with that, looking over at the window in the large living space, you needed to see your reflection.

You quickly got to your feet, almost falling forward due to your shift in center of gravity, and slowly walked to the window. And what you saw, made your jaw drop.

Your, no, her face...

It was a face that often chanded between graphical updates of consoles, but it was the face you knew from the plenty of hours you had put into the Metroid Prime Trilogy, and even Other M...

"I'm..." You began, "Samus..."

Somehow, you had become the legendary Bounty Hunter...
